author: David Flynn
title: Cathay Pacific drops 'Solus' airport lounge chair for new 'Solo' design
text:
Cathay Pacific will swap its iconic Solus workstation pod for a new chair dubbed the Solo which will debut at airport lounges later this year.
Created as a joint effort between Cathay Pacific, London-based design firm Foster + Partners and Italian luxury furniture manufacturer Poltrona Frau, the pod-like Solus chair has become a hallmark of the airline's lounges around the world.
Each of these futuristic pieces of furniture offers a self-contained space for the busy business traveller, complete with a small laptop/tablet desk and AC power.
Read: Inside story – the evolution of Cathay Pacific’s Solus chair
But just as Cathay Pacific has adopted a more relaxed and ‘residential’ feel for its newest airport lounges – as best exemplified by The Pier First Class Lounge at Hong Kong – so the high-tech Solus will make way for the more unassuming Solo.
“The Solo chair is a replacement for the Solus chair; it’s going to warmer, softer and more in keeping with the new lounge design values,” Cathay Pacific’s General Manager of Product, Toby Smith, tells Australian Business Traveller .
“But it will have the same level of functionality – a personal light, power sockets – it will be a very flexible private workspace.”
Like Cathay’s new-look lounges, the Solo chair has been designed by Ilse Crawford of Studio Crawford.
Production has recently started on the Solo, and Smith says “we hope to have them in three months, perhaps less.”
“I think Taipei will be the first lounge to have them when it opens, and then we’ll swap out some of the existing furniture to put them into the other new lounges like Bangkok, Manila and Haneda – and of course Vancouver, Heathrow and The Pier Business Class when those open next year.”
